title: Meopham Walks

images.title: Robin Webster / Meopham Green
images.caption: Meopham Green and windmill view. A picturesque triangular green with views all round, not just in this direction. The windmill was built in 1801. It was restored in 2005 by the council and is now open to the public for part of the year.

images.title: Valley View near Meopham by Roger Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Valley View near Meopham

images.title: Camer Country Park by Robin Webster, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Camer Country Park

images.title: Danny Robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footpath Junction Near Luddesdown. Where the Wealdway turns right and goes down hill.

images.title: Stephen Craven / Church of St Peter & St Paul, Luddesdown
images.caption: Church of St Peter & St Paul, Luddesdown. Grade II* listed Anglican church, with 13th century origins but largely rebuilt in the 19th century.

images.title: Lisa Fulcher / Luddesdown Court and church
images.caption: Luddesdown Court and church

description:
This Kent based village has a number of local woods and parks to visit. The village itself includes a picturesque village green with a cricket pitch and restored windmill. The wonderful scenery of the North Downs is also nearby opening up many walking possibilities. This walk from the village takes you east to Camer Park and the neighbouring village of Luddesdown. You can follow public footpaths east from the village, past Meopham Court to the country park. There's a number of trails here to follow around the park's 40 acres of ancient parkland, grassland and woods.
You can also pick up the long distance Wealdway here and follow it to the nearby village of Luddesdown. The pretty village includes some interesting buildings such as Luddesdown Court and a 13th century Grade II listed church.
